questions.text: True statement(s) regarding loop of Henley in kidney is/are?

options.label: C
options.text: Ascending limb secretes water in lumen

options.label: E
options.text: Descending limb receives hyperosmolar fluid from PCT

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation: Water reabsorption
  • • In PCT, the fluid in tubule is isotonic, with osmolarity of 300 mosm/L Due to water moving out in descending limb of loop of Henle, the fluid becomes hypertonic, reaching as high as 1200 mosm/L As fluid enters ascending limb of loop of Henle, due to movement of Na and Cl outside, the fluid again starts becoming hypotonic. The fluid entering early DCT is always hypotonic Finally, osmolarity starts rising in late DCT due to Na and Cl movement to the outside. In terminal DCT and collecting tubules, the osmolarity changes according to water permeability, as governed by ADH. Under the influence of ADH (which increases only water reabsorption, not solutes), another 10-12% water is reabsorbed, thereby increasing the tonicity.
  • • In PCT, the fluid in tubule is isotonic, with osmolarity of 300 mosm/L
  • • Due to water moving out in descending limb of loop of Henle, the fluid becomes hypertonic, reaching as high as 1200 mosm/L
  • • As fluid enters ascending limb of loop of Henle, due to movement of Na and Cl outside, the fluid again starts becoming hypotonic.
  • • The fluid entering early DCT is always hypotonic
  • • Finally, osmolarity starts rising in late DCT due to Na and Cl movement to the outside.
  • • In terminal DCT and collecting tubules, the osmolarity changes according to water permeability, as governed by ADH.
  • • Under the influence of ADH (which increases only water reabsorption, not solutes), another 10-12% water is reabsorbed, thereby increasing the tonicity.
  • • Remember: Aldosterone acts on cortical collecting duct whereas ADH acts on medullary collecting duct
  • • Remember:
